title: Do you need a college degree to work in IT? - Quora

response.answer_text: A degree is only a piece of paper…it’s what you learn that counts, but many companies won’t hire someone without a college degree into management-level jobs or jobs demanding a critical technical skill. Going to college is like “going to the gym for your mind”. “Do I need to go to the gym to get in top physical condition?” If you’re self-disciplined enough, have the right resources, and know what you’re doing; you can get in shape without going to the gym. Similarly you can learn some of the same material you would learn in college on your own. However, going to college can be a life-changing experience in many ways. You may forget many of the facts but you will remember problem-solving techniques and thought patterns for the rest of your life. Whether you need a degree or not will also depend on the job - “IT” is a very broad area.

I don't think you have to have a degree, but it will depend on want you want to do in IT and what kind of skills you have. If you want to write code, the more languages you know the better c++, java, javascript etc. If you want to do software testing you don't necessarily need to know how to code but you need to be logical and be able to follow the project requirements. I personally don't think a degree is the distinguishing factor for a good IT employee. If you already have good skills play them up on your resume. There are a lot of really good IT people out there that don't have degrees.

Without one, you will be working as an entry level IT support (and perhaps you can move up a little, in due course), but at a larger company, you will never run the department, if that is what you want. I work for a large company - and a couple of jobs ago, a similar sized company - both manager of the IT department has PhD in computer science. They certainly make a lot of money, and if that is what you want, you should get a computer science degree.

No, but you need programming skills. The internet is full of tutorials for nearly each language and full of blogs how good code should look like. Do the tutorials, understand the design patterns and practise, practise, practise. Then you can word as a software developer, devops whatever
No, but if you want to advance quicker in IT and get a better understanding of the basics you'll need a college degree.
